answers.author: Lawrence Di Re
answers.text:
I'm not using this page to sell anything.  Is this a RFP posting for consulting services?  Here ares some sources you might consider:  City of Madison http://www.cityofmadison.com/planning/bpg_final_for%20weba.pdf  ; City of Missoula http://www.ci.missoula.mt.us/DocumentCenter/Home/View/5475 ; District of Columbia https://www.communicationsmgr.com/projects/1355/docs/Zoning_BPs_whole.pdf ; Nine step best practices model from Australia http://www.landcom.com.au/downloads/uploaded/Best_Practice_6771_b109.pdf ;  David Ammons' UNC School of Government publication http://sogpubs.unc.edu/electronicversions/pdfs/developmentreviewtoc.pdf 
Without knowing the specifics of the community involved these are all sources with generalizable processes that may be effective in "breaking the cycle".  That is an interesting phrase in and of itself, but since the post is coming from someone outside the community I will not speculate on other issues that may be causing the "public reaction" mentioned.
I would also advise the community involved to be open to a localized process to build transparency and communication into the development review process.  Paying high-priced consultants inc. $150.00 an hour to read any of the sources I listed to them is surely not the best first step.

answers.author: Mike Cohen
answers.text:
Cheryl,
I'm not sure what you mean by "break the cycle of public reaction". But if you mean, halt a common pattern of public reaction that is full of misinformation, vitriol and personal attacks, then you might recommend an online forum platform and corresponding best practice protocols that are optimized for civility and insight -- such as Peak Democracy Inc's Open Town Hall service (http://www.PeakDemocracy.com).
Mike

answers.author: Amelia McCulley
answers.text:
In Albemarle County, Virginia, we are about to implement a new process for legislative applications (special use permits and rezonings) that requires the developer to hold a community meeting prior to public hearings.  The idea is to have them establish that relationship and obtain input and provide information before it get very contentious at a late decisionmaking point such as a public hearing.

author: Cheryl Hilvert
text:
I was recently contacted by a member who is interested is learning about alternative procedures to "break the cycle" of public reaction to development review proposals.   They are interested in learning about any creative processes/best practices that have been employed by local governments in this area as well as any consultants that may be working in this area.  
Does anyone have any ideas to share?
title: Looking for Alternative/Supplemental Procedures for Receiving Public Input on Development Proposals
